<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
For other uses, see&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Horus (disambiguation)">Horus (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<table class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-infobox" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(162 , 169 , 177); clear: right; color: black; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 12.32px; line-height: 1.5em; margin: 0.5em 0px 0.5em 1em; padding: 0.2em; width: 22em;"><tbody>
<tr><th colspan="2" style="background-color: rgb(222 , 205 , 135); font-size: 15.4px; text-align: center; vertical-align: top;">Horus</th></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align: center; vertical-align: top;"><span style="font-size: 13.552px;"><b>God of the sky and kingship</b></span></td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align: center; vertical-align: top;"><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-image" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Horus_standing.svg" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank"><img alt="Horus standing.svg" height="503" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Horus_standing.svg/220px-Horus_standing.svg.png" style="border: 0px; vertical-align: middle;" width="220" /></a><br />
<div>
Horus was often the ancient Egyptians' national&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutelary_deity" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Tutelary deity">tutelary deity</a>. He was usually depicted as a falcon-headed man wearing the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pschent" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Pschent">pschent</a></i>, or a red and white crown, as a symbol of kingship over the entire kingdom of Egypt.</div>
</td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Major cult center</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edfu" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Edfu">Edfu</a></td></tr>

<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Consort</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serket" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Serket">Serket</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Elder),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hathor" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hathor">Hathor</a>(in one version)</td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Offspring</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imset" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Imset">Imset</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hapi_(Son_of_Horus)" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hapi (Son of Horus)">Hapi</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duamutef" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Duamutef">Duamutef</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qebehsenuef" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Qebehsenuef">Qebehse<wbr></wbr>nuef</a>&nbsp;(as Haroeris),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ihy" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Ihy">Ihy</a></td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Parents</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a></td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Siblings</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nephthys" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Nephthys">Nephthys</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Elder),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anubis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Anubis">Anubis</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Younger)</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Horus</b>&nbsp;is one of the most significant&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_deities" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Egyptian deities">ancient Egyptian deities</a>. He was worshipped from at least the late&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prehistoric_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Prehistoric Egypt">prehistoric Egypt</a>&nbsp;until the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt_(Roman_province)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egypt (Roman province)">Roman Egypt</a>. Different forms of Horus are recorded in history and these are treated as distinct gods by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptology" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egyptology">Egyptologists</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;These various forms may possibly be different perceptions of the same multi-layered deity in which certain attributes or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syncretism" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a>&nbsp;relationships are emphasized, not necessarily in opposition but complementary to one another, consistent with how the Ancient Egyptians viewed the multiple facets of reality.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup>&nbsp;He was most often depicted as a falcon, most likely a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanner_falcon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lanner falcon">lanner falcon</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peregrine_falcon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Peregrine falcon">peregrine falcon</a>, or as a man with a falcon head.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The earliest recorded form of Horus is the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutelary_deity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Tutelary deity">tutelary deity</a>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>, who is the first known national god, specifically related to the king who in time came to be regarded as a manifestation of Horus in life and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>&nbsp;in death.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;The most commonly encountered family relationship describes Horus as the son of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a>&nbsp;and Osiris, and he plays a key role in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris_myth" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Osiris myth">Osiris myth</a>&nbsp;as Osiris's heir and the rival to&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, the murderer of Osiris. In another tradition&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hathor" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hathor">Hathor</a>&nbsp;is regarded as his mother and sometimes as his wife.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>Horus served many functions, most notably being a god of the sky, war and hunting.</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">

<tr><th style="background: navajowhite; border-bottom: 1px solid peru; padding: 0.5em;">ḥr "Horus"<br />
in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">hieroglyphs</a></th></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus is recorded in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">Egyptian hieroglyphs</a>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<i>ḥr.w</i>&nbsp;"Falcon"; the pronunciation has been reconstructed as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">ħaːruw</span>. Additional meanings are thought to have been "the distant one" or "one who is above, over".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup>&nbsp;As the language changed over time, it appeared in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coptic_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Coptic language">Coptic</a>&nbsp;dialects variously as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">hoːɾ</span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">ħoːɾ</span>&nbsp;and was adopted into&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek">ancient Greek</a>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<span lang="grc">Ὧρος</span>&nbsp;<i>Hōros</i>&nbsp;(pronounce<wbr></wbr>d at the time as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">hoːɾos</span>). It also survives in Late Egyptian and Coptic&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theophoric_name" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Theophoric name">theophoric names</a>&nbsp;such as&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harsiese_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Harsiese (disambiguation)">Har-si-ese</a>&nbsp;"Horus, Son of Isis".</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Nekheny may have been another falcon god worshipped at&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>, city of the falcon, with whom Horus was identified from early on.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus may be shown as a falcon on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narmer_Palette" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Narmer Palette">Narmer Palette</a>, dating from about the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/31st_century_BC" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="31st century BC">31st century BC</a>.</div>

Horus was born to the goddess Isis after she retrieved all the dismembered body parts of her murdered husband Osiris, except his&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_penis#Object_of_worship" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Human penis">penis</a>, which was thrown into the Nile and eaten by a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catfish" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Catfish">catfish</a>,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>'s account used her magic powers to resurrect Osiris and fashion a golden&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phallus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Phallus">phallus</a><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-9" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-9" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[9]</a></sup>&nbsp;to conceive her son (older Egyptian accounts have the penis of Osiris surviving).</div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Once Isis knew she was pregnant with Horus, she fled to the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nile_Delta" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nile Delta">Nile Delta</a>&nbsp;marshlands to hide from her brother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, who jealously killed Osiris and who she knew would want to kill their son.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-World_mythology_10-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-World_mythology-10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[10]</a></sup>&nbsp;There Isis bore a divine son, Horus.</div>

in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">hieroglyphs</a></th></tr>

<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Sky_god">Sky god</span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Since Horus was said to be the sky, he was considered to also contain the sun and moon.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;It became said<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (January 2016)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;that the sun was his right eye and the moon his left, and that they traversed the sky when he, a falcon, flew across it. Later, the reason that the moon was not as bright as the sun was explained by a tale, known as&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Contendings_of_Horus_and_Seth" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Contendings of Horus and Seth">The Contendings of Horus and Seth</a></i>. In this tale, it was said that Set, the patron of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>, and Horus, the patron of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lower Egypt">Lower Egypt</a>, had battled for Egypt brutally, with neither side victorious, until eventually the gods sided with Horus.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
As Horus was the ultimate victor he became known as&nbsp;<i>ḥr.w wr</i>&nbsp;"Horus the Great", but more usually translated "Horus the Elder". In the struggle, Set had lost a testicle, explaining why the desert, which Set represented, is infertile. Horus' left eye had also been gouged out, then a new eye was created by part of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khonsu" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Khonsu">Khonsu</a>, the moon god, and was replaced.</div>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tleft" style="clear: left; float: left; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">

<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbcaption" style="border: 0px; font-size: 12.3704px; line-height: 1.4em; padding: 3px; text-align: left;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-magnify" style="float: right; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 0px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-internal" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Eye_of_Horus.svg" style="color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128); display: block; height: 11px; overflow: hidden; text-indent: 15px; white-space: nowrap; width: 15px;" target="_blank" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eye_of_Horus" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Eye of Horus">Eye of Horus</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<i>Wedjat</i></div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eye_of_Horus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Eye of Horus">Eye of Horus</a>&nbsp;is an ancient Egyptian symbol of protection and royal power from deities, in this case from Horus or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ra" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ra">Ra</a>. The symbol is seen on images of Horus' mother, Isis, and on other deities associated with her. In the Egyptian language, the word for this symbol was "wedjat" (<i>wɟt</i>).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-13" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-14" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-14" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[14]</a></sup>It was the eye of one of the earliest of Egyptian deities,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wadjet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wadjet">Wadjet</a>, who later became associated with&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bastet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Bastet">Bastet</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mut" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mut">Mut</a>, and Hathor as well. Wadjet was a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_deity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Solar deity">solar deity</a>&nbsp;and this symbol began as her all-seeing eye. In early artwork, Hathor is also depicted with this eye.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-15" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-15" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[15]</a></sup>&nbsp;Funerary amulets were often made in the shape of the Eye of Horus. The Wedjat or Eye of Horus is "the central element" of seven "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Gold">gold</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faience" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Faience">faience</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnelian" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Carnelian">carnelian</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lapis_lazuli" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lapis lazuli"><wbr></wbr>lapis lazuli</a>" bracelets found on the mummy of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoshenq_II" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Shoshenq II">Shoshenq II</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Silverman_16-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-Silverman-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;The Wedjat "was intended to protect the king [here] in the afterlife"<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Silverman_16-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-Silverman-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;and to ward off evil. Egyptian and Near Eastern sailors would frequently paint the symbol on the bow of their vessel to ensure safe sea travel.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-17" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[17]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Conflict_between_Horus_and_Set">Conflict between Horus and Set</span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tright" style="clear: right; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbinner" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); font-size: 13.16px; min-width: 100px; overflow: hidden; padding: 3px; text-align: center; width: 222px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-image" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank"><img alt="" class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbimage" height="125" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg/220px-Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="background-color: rgb(255 , 255 , 255); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); vertical-align: middle;" width="220" /></a><br />
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbcaption" style="border: 0px; font-size: 12.3704px; line-height: 1.4em; padding: 3px; text-align: left;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-magnify" style="float: right; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 0px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-internal" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128); display: block; height: 11px; overflow: hidden; text-indent: 15px; white-space: nowrap; width: 15px;" target="_blank" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Horus,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvre" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Louvre">Louvre</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shen_ring" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Shen ring">Shen rings</a>&nbsp;in his grasp</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus was told by his mother, Isis, to protect the people of Egypt from&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, the god of the desert, who had killed Horus' father, Osiris.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-19" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-20" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup>&nbsp;Horus had many battles with Set, not only to avenge his father, but to choose the rightful ruler of Egypt. In these battles, Horus came to be associated with Lower Egypt, and became its patron.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
According to&nbsp;<i>The Contendings of Horus and Seth</i>, Set is depicted as trying to prove his dominance by seducing Horus and then having&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_intercourse" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Sexual intercourse">sexual intercourse</a>&nbsp;with him. However, Horus places his hand between his thighs and catches Set's&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Semen">semen</a>, then subsequently throws it in the river so that he may not be said to have been inseminated by Set. Horus then deliberately spreads his own semen on some&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lettuce" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lettuce">lettuce</a>, which was Set's favorite food. After Set had eaten the lettuce, they went to the gods to try to settle the argument over the rule of Egypt. The gods first listened to Set's claim of dominance over Horus, and call his semen forth, but it answered from the river, invalidating his claim. Then, the gods listened to Horus' claim of having dominated Set, and call his semen forth, and it answered from inside Set.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
gyptologists have often tried to connect the conflict between the two gods with political events early in Egypt's history or prehistory. The cases in which the combatants divide the kingdom, and the frequent association of the paired Horus and Set with the union of Upper and Lower Egypt, suggest that the two deities represent some kind of division within the country. Egyptian tradition and archaeological evidence indicate that Egypt was united at the beginning of its history when an Upper Egyptian kingdom, in the south, conquered Lower Egypt in the north. The Upper Egyptian rulers called themselves "followers of Horus", and Horus became the tutelary deity of the unified nation and its kings.&nbsp;</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Greek form of&nbsp;<b>Her-ur</b>&nbsp;(or&nbsp;<b>Har wer</b>) is&nbsp;<b>Haroeris</b>. Other variants include&nbsp;<b>Hor Merti</b>&nbsp;'Horus of the two eyes' and&nbsp;<b>Horkhenti Irti</b>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-29" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-29" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[29]</a></sup></div>

<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Homer</b>&nbsp;(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient&nbsp;Greek</a>:&nbsp;<span lang="grc">Ὅμηρος</span>&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Help:IPA for Greek">[<wbr></wbr>hómɛːros]</a></span>,&nbsp;<i>Hómēros</i>) is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odyssey" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odyssey">Odyssey</a></i>, two epic poems which are the central works of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_literature" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek literature">ancient Greek literature</a>. The&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;is set during the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>, the ten-year siege of the city of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Troy">Troy</a>&nbsp;by a coalition of Greek states. It focuses on a quarrel between King&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agamemnon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Agamemnon">Agamemnon</a>&nbsp;and the warrior&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>&nbsp;lasting a few weeks during the last year of the war. The&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;focuses on the journey home of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odysseus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>, king of Ithaca, after the fall of Troy.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Question" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Question">Homeric Question</a>—by whom, when, where and under what circumstances were the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;composed<wbr></wbr>—continues to be debated. Broadly speaking, modern scholarly opinion falls into two groups. One holds that most of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and (according to some) the&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;are the works of a single poet of genius. The other considers the Homeric poems to be the result of a process of working and re-working by many contributors, and that "Homer" is best seen as a label for an entire tradition.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-bgr_3-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-bgr-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;It is generally accepted that the poems were composed at some point around the late 8th or early 7th century&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Era" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Common Era">BCE</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup>&nbsp;The poems are in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Greek">Homeric Greek</a>, also known as Epic Greek, a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Literary language">literary language</a>&nbsp;which shows a mixture of features of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ionic_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ionic Greek">Ionic</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeolic_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Aeolic Greek">Aeolic</a>&nbsp;dialects from different centuries; the predominant influence is Eastern Ionic.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-6" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[6]</a></sup>&nbsp;Most researchers believe that the poems were originally transmitted orally.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px; <div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Various traditions have survived purporting to give details of Homer's birthplace and background. The satirist&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucian" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lucian">Lucian</a>, in his&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/True_History" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="True History">True History</a></i>, describes him as a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babylonia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Babylonia">Babylonian</a>&nbsp;called&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tigranes" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Tigranes">Tigranes</a>, who assumed the name Homer when taken "hostage" (<i>homeros</i>) by the Greeks.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-18" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-18" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[18]</a></sup>&nbsp;When the Emperor&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadrian" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a>&nbsp;asked the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Oracle">Oracle</a>&nbsp;at&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delphi" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer's Ithaca">Ithacan</a>, the son of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epikaste" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epikaste">Epikaste</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telemachus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Telemachus">Telemachus</a>, from the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odyssey" style="background-image: none; <h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Works_attributed_to_Homer">Works attributed to Homer</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Homer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Works attributed to Homer">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Greeks of the sixth and early fifth centuries BCE understood by the works of "Homer", generally, "the whole body of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_poetry" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epic poetry">heroic tradition</a>&nbsp;as embodied in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexameter" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hexameter">hexameter</a>&nbsp;verse".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-66" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-66" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[66]</a></sup>&nbsp;The entire&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_Cycle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epic Cycle">Epic Cycle</a>&nbsp;was included. The genre included further poems on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>, such as the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Iliad" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Little Iliad">Little Iliad</a></i>, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nostoi" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nostoi">Nostoi</a></i>, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cypria" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Cypria">Cypria</a></i>, and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epigoni_(epic)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epigoni (epic)">Epigoni</a></i>, as well as the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thebes,_Greece" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thebes, Greece">Theban</a>&nbsp;poems about&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oedipus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Oedipus">Oedipus</a>&nbsp;and his sons. Other works, such as the corpus of&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Hymns" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Hymns">Homeric Hymns</a></i>, the comic mini-epic&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batrachomyomachia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Batrachomyomachia">Batrachomyomachia</a></i>&nbsp;("<wbr></wbr>The Frog-Mouse War"), and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margites" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Margites">Margites</a></i>, were also attributed to him. Two other poems, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capture_of_Oechalia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Capture of Oechalia">Capture of Oechalia</a></i>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phocais" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Phocais">Phocais</a></i>, were also assigned Homeric authorship.</div>

</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>&nbsp;remarks in his&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poetics_(Aristotle)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Poetics (Aristotle)">Poetics</a></i>&nbsp;that Homer was unique among the poets of his time, focusing on a single unified theme or action in the epic cycle.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-94" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-94" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[94]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The cardinal qualities of the style of Homer are well articulated by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Arnold" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Matthew Arnold">Matthew Arnold</a>:</div>
<blockquote style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 1em 0px; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px 40px;">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
[T]he translator of Homer should above all be penetrated by a sense of four qualities of his author:—that he is eminently rapid; that he is eminently plain and direct, both in the evolution of his thought and in the expression of it, that is, both in his syntax and in his words; that he is eminently plain and direct in the substance of his thought, that is, in his matter and ideas; and finally, that he is eminently noble.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-95" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-95" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[95]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
One often finds books of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;cited by the corresponding letter of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_alphabet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Greek alphabet">Greek alphabet</a>, with upper-case letters referring to a book number of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and lower-case letters referring to the&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>. Thus Ξ 200 would be shorthand for&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;book 14, line 200, while ξ 200 would be&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;14.200. The following table presents this system of numeration:</div>

<h4 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Divine_Intervention">Divine Intervention</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Divine Intervention">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h4>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Some scholars believe that the gods may have intervened in the mortal world because of quarrels they may have had among each other.&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer">Homer</a>&nbsp;interprets the world at this time by using the passion and emotion of the gods to be determining factors of what happens on the human level.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-:0_15-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-:0-15" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[15]</a></sup>&nbsp;An example of one of these relationships in the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;occurs between&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Athena">Athena</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hera">Hera</a>, and Aphrodite. In the final book of the poem Homer writes, "He offended Athena and Hera-both goddesses."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-:1_16-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-:1-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;Athena and Hera are envious of Aphrodite because of a beauty pageant on Mount Olympus in which&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Paris (mythology)">Paris</a>&nbsp;chose Aphrodite to be the most beautiful goddess over both Hera and Athena.&nbsp;</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Nostos">Nostos</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Nostos">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nostos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nostos">Nostos</a></i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">νόστος</span>, "homecoming") occurs seven times in the poem.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-17" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[17]</a></sup>&nbsp;Thematically, the concept of homecoming is much explored in Ancient Greek literature, especially in the post-war homeward fortunes experienced by the Atreidae (Agamemnon and Menelaus), and Odysseus (see the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odyssey" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odyssey">Odyssey</a></i>). Thus,&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>&nbsp;is impossible without sacking Troy—King Agamemnon's motive for winning, at any cost.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Kleos">Kleos</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Kleos">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Kleos">Kleos</a></i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">κλέος</span>, "glory, fame") is the concept of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glory" style="background-image: none; color: #663366;" target="_blank" title="wikt:glory">glory</a>&nbsp;earned in heroic battle.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-18" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-18" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[18]</a></sup>&nbsp;For most of the Greek invaders of Troy, notably&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odysseus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>,&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>&nbsp;is earned in a victorious&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>(homecoming). Yet, Achilles must choose only one of the two rewards, either&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-19" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup>&nbsp;In Book IX (IX.410–16), he poignantly tells Agamemnon's envoys—Odysseus, Phoenix, Ajax—begging his reinstatement to battle about having to choose between two fates (<span lang="grc">διχθαδίας κήρας</span>, 9.411).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-autogenerated1_20-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-autogenerated1-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The passage reads:</div>
<table style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin-left: 3em;"><tbody>
<tr><td><div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-poem" lang="">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<span lang="grc">μήτηρ γάρ τέ μέ φησι θεὰ Θέτις ἀργυρόπεζα (410)<br />διχθαδίας κῆρας φερέμεν θανάτοιο τέλος δέ.<br />εἰ μέν κ' αὖθι μένων Τρώων πόλιν ἀμφιμάχωμαι,<br />ὤλετο μέν μοι νόστος, ἀτὰρ κλέος ἄφθιτον ἔσται<br />εἰ δέ κεν οἴκαδ' ἵκωμι φίλην ἐς πατρίδα γαῖαν,<br />ὤλετό μοι κλέος ἐσθλόν, ἐπὶ δηρὸν δέ μοι αἰὼν (415)<br />ἔσσεται, οὐδέ κέ μ' ὦκα τέλος θανάτοιο κιχείη.</span><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</td><td style="padding-left: 2em;"><div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-poem">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
For my mother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thetis">Thetis</a>&nbsp;the goddess of silver feet tells me<br />
I carry two sorts of destiny toward the day of my death. Either,<br />
if I stay here and fight beside the city of the Trojans,<br />
my return home is gone, but my glory shall be everlasting;<br />
but if I return home to the beloved land of my fathers,<br />
the excellence of my glory is gone, but there will be a long life<br />
left for me, and my end in death will not come to me quickly.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</td></tr>
<tr style="font-size: 12.32px; vertical-align: top;"><td></td><td style="padding-left: 2em;">—Translated by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_Lattimore" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Richmond Lattimore">Richmond Lattimore</a></td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
In forgoing his&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>, he will earn the greater reward of&nbsp;<i>kleos aphthiton</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">κλέος ἄφθιτον</span>, "fame imperishable").<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-autogenerated1_20-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-autogenerated1-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup>&nbsp;In the poem,&nbsp;<i>aphthiton</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">ἄφθιτον</span>, "imperishable") occurs five other times,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-23" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup>&nbsp;each occurrence denotes an object: Agamemnon's sceptre, the wheel of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebe_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebe (mythology)">Hebe</a>'s chariot, the house of Poseidon, the throne of Zeus, the house of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hephaestus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hephaestus">Hephaestus</a>. Translator&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_Lattimore" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Richmond Lattimore">Lattimore</a>&nbsp;renders&nbsp;<i>k<wbr></wbr>leos aphthiton</i>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<i>forever immortal</i>&nbsp;and as&nbsp;<i>forever imperishable</i>—connoting Achilles's mortality by underscoring his greater reward in returning to battle Troy.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Kleos is often given visible representation by the prizes won in battle. When Agamemnon takes Briseis from Achilles, he takes away a portion of the kleos he had earned.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Achilles' shield, crafted by Hephaestus and given to him by his mother Thetis, bears an image of stars in the centre. The stars conjure profound images of the place of a single man, no matter how heroic, in the perspective of the entire cosmos.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Tim.C3.AA">Timê</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Timê">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Akin to&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<i>timê</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">τιμή</span>, "respect, honor"), the concept denoting the respectability an honorable man accrues with accomplishment (cultural, political, martial), per his station in life. In Book I, the Greek troubles begin with King Agamemnon's dishonorable, unkingly behavior—first, by threatening the priest Chryses (1.11), then, by aggravating them in disrespecting Achilles, by confiscating Briseis from him (1.171). The warrior's consequent rancor against the dishonorable king ruins the Greek military cause.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Wrath">Wrath</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Wrath">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tright" style="clear: right; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbinner" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); font-size: 13.16px; min-width: 100px; overflow: hidden; padding: 3px; text-align: center; width: 252px;">

<i>The Wrath of Achilles</i>&nbsp;(1819), by Michel Drolling.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The poem's initial word,&nbsp;<span lang="grc">μῆνιν</span>&nbsp;(<i>mēnin</i>,&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accusative" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Accusative">accusative</a><wbr></wbr>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<span lang="grc">μῆνις</span>,&nbsp;<i>mēnis</i>, "wrath, rage, fury"), establishes the&nbsp;<i>Iliad's</i>&nbsp;principal theme: The "Wrath of Achilles".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup>&nbsp;His personal rage and wounded soldier's vanity propel the story: the Greeks' faltering in battle, the slayings of Patroclus and Hector, and the fall of Troy. In Book I, the Wrath of Achilles first emerges in the Achilles-convoked meeting, between the Greek kings and the seer&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calchas" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Calchas">Calchas</a>. King Agamemnon dishonours Chryses, the Trojan priest of Apollo, by refusing with a threat the restitution of his daughter, Chryseis—despite the proffered ransom of "gifts beyond count".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-25" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;The insulted priest prays his god's help, and a nine-day rain of divine plague arrows falls upon the Greeks. Moreover, in that meeting, Achilles accuses Agamemnon of being "greediest for gain of all men".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup>&nbsp;To that, Agamemnon replies:</div>
<blockquote style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 1em 0px; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px 40px;">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
But here is my threat to you.<br />
Even as Phoibos Apollo is taking away my Chryseis.<br />
I shall convey her back in my own ship, with my own<br />
followers; but I shall take the fair-cheeked Briseis,<br />
your prize, I myself going to your shelter, that you may learn well<br />
how much greater I am than you, and another man may shrink back<br />
from likening himself to me and contending against me.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-27" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-27" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[27]</a></sup></div>
</blockquote>

<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Homer Jay Simpson</b>&nbsp;is a fictional character and the main protagonist of the American animated television series&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i>&nbsp;as the patriarch of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simpson_family" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Simpson family">eponymous family</a>. He is voiced by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Castellaneta" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Dan Castellaneta">Dan Castellaneta</a>&nbsp;and first appeared on television, along with the rest of his family, in&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tracey_Ullman_Show" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Tracey Ullman Show">The Tracey Ullman Show</a></i>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons_shorts" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons shorts">short</a>&nbsp;"<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Night_(The_Simpsons_short)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Good Night (The Simpsons short)">Good Night</a>" on April 19, 1987. Homer was created and designed by cartoonist&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Groening" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Matt Groening">Matt Groening</a>&nbsp;while he was waiting in the lobby of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_L._Brooks" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="James L. Brooks">James L. Brooks</a>' office. Groening had been called to pitch a series of shorts based on his comic strip&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_in_Hell" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Life in Hell">Life in Hell</a></i>&nbsp;but instead decided to create a new set of characters. He named the character after his father, Homer Groening. After appearing for three seasons on&nbsp;<i>The Tracey Ullman Show</i>, the Simpson family got their own series on&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>&nbsp;that debuted December 17, 1989.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Homer and his wife&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marge_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Marge Simpson">Marge</a>&nbsp;have three children:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bart_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Bart Simpson">Bart</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lisa Simpson">Lisa</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maggie_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Maggie Simpson">Maggie</a>. As the family's provider, he works at the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield_(The_Simpsons)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Springfield (The Simpsons)">Springfield Nuclear Power Plant</a>&nbsp;as safety inspector. Homer embodies several American&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Working class">working class</a>&nbsp;stereotypes: he is a crude, bald, obese, short-tempered, neglectful of the rules, clumsy, lazy, heavy drinking, ignorant and idiotic person; however, he is essentially a decent man and fiercely devoted to his family. Despite the suburban&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue-collar_worker" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Blue-collar worker">blue-collar</a>&nbsp;routine of his life, he has had a number of remarkable experiences.</div>
<div>

<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Homer made his debut with the rest of the Simpson family on April 19, 1987, in&nbsp;<i>The Tracey Ullman Show</i>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons_shorts" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons shorts">short</a>&nbsp;"<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Night_(The_Simpsons_short)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Good Night (The Simpsons short)">Good Night</a>".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichmond_.26_Coffman199714_25-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichmond_.26_Coffman199714-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;In 1989, the shorts were adapted into&nbsp;<i>The Simpsons</i>, a half-hour series airing on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox Broadcasting Company</a>. Homer and the Simpson family remained the main characters on this new show.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup></div>
