<h2 align="center" class="gmail-pageName">
The Legend of St. George and the Dragon</h2>
<img align="left" alt="St George" src="http://projectbritain.com/stgeorge/stgeorge.jpg" height="300" hspace="20" width="114" /><br />
<span style="font-size: x-small;">St. George travelled for many months by land and sea until he came to Libya. Here he met a poor hermit who told him that everyone in that land was in great distress, for a dragon had long ravaged the country.</span><br />
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span>
<span style="font-size: x-small;">'<span class="gmail-style4">Every day</span>,' said the old man, '<span class="gmail-style4">he demands the sacrifice of a beautiful maiden and now all the young girls have been killed. The king's daughter alone remains, and unless we can find a knight who can slay the dragon she will be sacrificed tomorrow. The king of Egypt will give his daughter in marriage to the champion who overcomes this terrible monster.</span>'</span><br />
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span>
<span style="font-size: x-small;">When St. George heard this story, he was determined to try and save the princess, so he rested that night in the hermit's hut, and at daybreak set out to the valley where the dragon lived. When he drew near he saw a little procession of women, headed by a beautiful girl dressed in pure Arabian silk. The princess Sabra was being led by her attendants to the place of death. The knight spurred his horse and overtook the ladies. He comforted them with brave words and persuaded the princess to return to the palace. Then he entered the valley.</span><br />
<div align="center">
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><img alt="George slaying the dragon" border="2" src="http://projectbritain.com/stgeorge/pic.jpg" height="200" width="263" /></span></div>
<div align="center">
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span></div>
<span style="font-size: x-small;">As soon as the dragon saw him it rushed from its cave, roaring with a sound louder than thunder. Its head was immense and its tail fifty feet long. But St. George was not afraid. He struck the monster with his spear, hoping he would wound it.</span><br />
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span>
<br />
<div align="center">
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><img alt="Fstival of History" border="1" src="http://projectbritain.com/stgeorge/festival.jpg" height="300" width="483" /></span></div>
<div align="center">
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span></div>
<span style="font-size: x-small;">The dragon's scales were so hard that the spear broke into a thousand pieces. and St. George fell from his horse. Fortunately he rolled under an enchanted orange tree against which poison could not prevail, so that the venomous dragon was unable to hurt him. Within a few minutes he had recovered his strength and was able to fight again.</span><br />
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br align="center" div="" /></span>
<div style="text-align: center;">
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><img alt="St George fights the dragon with his sword" border="1" src="http://projectbritain.com/stgeorge/sword.jpg" height="300" width="429" /></span></div>
</div>
<span style="font-size: x-small;"><br /></span>
<span style="font-size: x-small;">He smote the beast with his sword, but the dragon poured poison on him and his armour split in two. Once more he refreshed himself from the orange tree and then, with his sword in his hand, he rushed at the dragon and pierced it under the wing where there were no scales, so that it fell dead at his feet.</span><br />
<br />
<img alt="The dragon is killed" border="1" src="http://projectbritain.com/stgeorge/dragon.jpg" height="238" style="display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;" width="441" /><br />
<br />

<blockquote class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-templatequote" style="margin: 1em 0px; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px 40px;">
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The same night he arose and took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven children, and crossed the ford of the Jabbok. He took them and sent them across the stream, and everything else that he had. And Jacob was left alone. And a man wrestled with him until the breaking of the day. When the man saw that he did not prevail against Jacob, he touched his hip socket, and Jacob's hip was put out of joint as he wrestled with him. Then he said, "Let me go, for the day has broken." But Jacob said, "I will not let you go unless you bless me." And he said to him, "What is your name?" And he said, "Jacob." Then he said, "Your name shall no longer be called Jacob, but Israel, for you have striven with God and with men, and have prevailed." Then Jacob asked him, "Please tell me your name." But he said, "Why is it that you ask my name?" And there he blessed him. So Jacob called the name of the place Peniel, saying, "For I have seen God face to face, and yet my life has been delivered." The sun rose upon him as he passed Penuel, limping because of his hip. Therefore to this day the people of Israel do not eat the sinew of the thigh that is on the hip socket, because he touched the socket of Jacob's hip on the sinew of the thigh.</div>

<h1 class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" lang="en" style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: none; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 1.8em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 0px 0px 0.25em; overflow: visible; padding: 0px;">
Achilles' heel</h1>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-body-content" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: 1.6;">
<div id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-siteSub" style="font-size: 12.88px;">
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-templatequotecite" style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.5em; margin-top: 0px; padding-left: 1.6em;">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
In&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_mythology" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Greek mythology">Greek mythology</a>, when&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>&nbsp;was a baby, it was foretold that he would die young. To prevent his death, his mother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thetis">Thetis</a>&nbsp;took&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styx" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Styx">River Styx</a>, which was supposed to offer powers of invulnerability, and dipped his body into the water; however, as Thetis held Achilles by the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heel" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Heel">heel</a>, his heel was not washed over by the water of the magical river. Achilles grew up to be a man of war who survived many great battles. One day, a poisonous arrow shot at him was lodged in his heel, killing him shortly afterwards.</div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The death of Achilles was not mentioned in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer">Homer</a>'s&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i>, but appeared in later Greek and Roman poetry and drama<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_heel#cite_note-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;concerning events after the Iliad, later in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>. In the myths surrounding the war, Achilles was said to have died from a heel wound which was the result of an arrow—possibly poisoned—shot by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Paris (mythology)">Paris</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_heel#cite_note-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Classical myths attribute Achilles's invulnerability to his mother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thetis">Thetis</a>&nbsp;having treated him with&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrosia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ambrosia">ambrosia</a>&nbsp;and burned away his mortality in the hearth fire except on the heel, by which she held him. Peleus, his father, discovered the treatment and was alarmed to see Thetis holding the baby in the flames, which offended her and made her leave the treatment incomplete.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_heel#cite_note-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;According to a myth arising later, his mother had dipped the infant Achilles in the river&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styx_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Styx (mythology)">Styx</a>, holding onto him by his heel, and he became invulnerable where the waters touched him—that is, everywhere except the areas of his heel that were covered by her thumb and forefinger.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_heel#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The use of "Achilles heel" as an expression meaning "area of weakness, vulnerable spot" dates only to 1840, with implied use in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Taylor_Coleridge" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Samuel Taylor Coleridge">Samuel Taylor Coleridge</a>'s "Ireland, that vulnerable heel of the British Achilles!" from 1810 (<i>Oxford English Dictionary</i>).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_heel#cite_note-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup></div>
</div>

<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">

color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Peniel (biblical)">Peniel</a>&nbsp;(Hebrew for Face of God), and has "God" in Gen 32:30 where Jacob says "For I have seen God face to face."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; Of the ancient Christian translations the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulgate" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>&nbsp;follows Hebrew "man" in 32:24 as "man",<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[7]</a></sup>&nbsp;and Hebrew "face of God" in 32:30 as "face of God".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-8" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-8" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[8]</a></sup>&nbsp;The&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syriac_Peshitta" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Syriac Peshitta">Syriac Peshitta</a>&nbsp;like Latin and Greek follows the Hebrew with first "man", then "face of God" in Genesis, but then in Hosea 12:4 preserves the Hebrew "angel".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-9" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-9" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[9]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Jewish_interpretations">Jewish interpretations</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Jewish interpretations">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>

Though some have questioned whether the Hebrew word&nbsp;<i>malakh</i>&nbsp;may be a later change here.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-12" style="font-size: 11.2px; <span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Christian_interpretations">Christian interpretations</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Christian interpretations">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Both&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Calvin" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="John Calvin">John Calvin</a>&nbsp;believed that Jacob had wrestled with God, although Calvin believed the event was only a vision.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Springer_13-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-Springer-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Barker_(minister)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Joseph Barker (minister)">Joseph Barker</a>&nbsp;(1854) believed the Bible clearly showed that Jacob wrestled with God.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_L._Berger" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Peter L. Berger">Peter L. Berger</a>&nbsp;also believed Jacob wrestled God.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
According to popular author&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosemary_Ellen_Guiley" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Rosemary Ellen Guiley">Rosemary Ellen Guiley</a>, "This dramatic scene has spurred much commentary from Judaic, Catholic, and Protestant theologians, biblical scholars, and literary critics. Does Jacob wrestle with God or with an angel?...There is no definitive answer, but the story has been rationalized, romanticized, treated as myth, and treated symbolically."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-23" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Among some Christian interpreters, this incident is thought to be a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christophany" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Christophany">Christophany</a>:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Douglas_MacMillan" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="J. Douglas MacMillan">J. Douglas MacMillan</a>&nbsp;(1991) suggests that the angel with whom Jacob wrestles is a "pre-incarnation appearance of Christ in the form of a man."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
According to one Christian commentary of the Bible incident described, "Jacob said, 'I saw God face to face'. Jacob's remark does not necessarily mean that the 'man' with whom he wrestled is God. Rather, as with other, similar statements, when one saw the 'angel of the Lord,' it was appropriate to claim to have seen the face of God."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-25" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Muslim_interpretation">Muslim interpretation</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Muslim interpretation">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Muslim authors have interpreted the incident as Jacob wrestling with God and mention it as one of the ridiculous stories of the Bible.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_wrestling_with_the_angel#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup></div>

He is one of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelve_Minor_Prophets" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Twelve Minor Prophets">Twelve Prophets</a>&nbsp;of the Jewish&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>, also known as the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_Prophets" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Minor Prophets">Minor Prophets</a>&nbsp;of the Christian&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Testament" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a>. Hosea is often seen as a "prophet of doom", but underneath his message of destruction is a promise of restoration. The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talmud" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Talmud">Talmud</a>&nbsp;(<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pesachim" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Pesachim">Pesachim</a></i>&nbsp;87a) claims that he was the greatest prophet of his generation. The period of Hosea's ministry extended to some sixty years and he was the only prophet of Israel of his time who left any written prophecy.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hosea#cite_note-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup></div>

<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Name">Name</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hosea&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Name">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The name "Hosea", meaning "salvation", or "He saves", or "He helps", seems to have been not uncommon, being derived from the auspicious verb from which we have the frequently recurring word "salvation". It may be a contraction of a larger form of which the divine name (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetragrammaton" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Tetragrammaton">YHWH</a>) or its abbreviation formed a part, so as to signify "YHWH helps". According to the Bible&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.bibler.org/versions/american_standard/asv_numbers13_sml.htm#numbers_13:8" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">Numbers 13:8</a>,&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.bibler.org/versions/american_standard/asv_numbers13_sml.htm#numbers_13:16" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">13:16</a>&nbsp;that was the original name of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Joshua">Joshua, son of Nun</a>, until&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moses" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Moses">Moses</a>&nbsp;gave him the longer,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theophoric_name" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Theophoric name">theophoric name</a>&nbsp;<i>Yehoshua</i>, "YHWH is salvation".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hosea#cite_note-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup></div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Location">Location</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hosea&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Location">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Although it is not expressly stated in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Hosea" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Book of Hosea">Book of Hosea</a>, it is apparent from the level of detail and familiarity focused on northern geography, that Hosea conducted his prophetic ministries in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Northern Israel (Samaria)</a>&nbsp;of which he was a native.</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Family">Family</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hosea&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Family">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Little is known about the life or social status of Hosea. According to the Book of Hosea, he married the prostitute&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gomer_(wife_of_Hosea)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Gomer (wife of Hosea)">Gomer</a>, the daughter of Diblaim, at&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="God">God</a>'s command.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hosea#cite_note-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;In&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt1305.htm#8" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">Hosea 5:8</a>&nbsp;ff., there is a reference to the wars which led to the capture of the kingdom by the Assyrians (ca. 734–732 BC). It is not certain if he had also experienced the destruction of Samaria, which is foreseen in&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt1314.htm#1" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">Hosea 14:1</a>.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Hosea's family life reflected the "adulterous" relationship which Israel had built with polytheistic gods. The relationship between Hosea and Gomer parallels the relationship between God and Israel. Even though Gomer runs away from Hosea and sleeps with another man, he loves her anyway and forgives her. Likewise, even though the people of Israel worshipped false gods, God continued to love them and did not abandon his covenant with them.</div>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tleft" style="clear: left; float: left; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">

<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-internal" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_063.jpg" style="color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128); display: block; height: 11px; overflow: hidden; text-indent: 15px; white-space: nowrap; width: 15px;" target="_blank" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<i>The Prophet Hosea</i>, by&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duccio_di_Buoninsegna" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Duccio di Buoninsegna">Duccio di Buoninsegna</a>, in the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cathedral_(Siena)" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Cathedral (Siena)">Siena Cathedral</a>(c. 1309-1311)</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Similarly, his children's names made them like walking prophecies of the fall of the ruling dynasty and the severed covenant with God – much like the prophet&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaiah" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Isaiah">Isaiah</a>&nbsp;a generation later. The name of Hosea's daughter, Lo-ruhamah, which translates as "not pitied", is chosen by God as a sign of displeasure with the people of Israel for following false gods. (In Hosea 2:23 she is redeemed, shown mercy with the term&nbsp;<i>Ruhamah</i>.) The name of Hosea's son, Lo-ammi, which translates as "not my people", is chosen by the Lord as a sign of the Lord's displeasure with the people of Israel for following those false gods (see Hosea 1:8-9).</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Christian_thought">Christian thought</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hosea&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Christian thought">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
One of the early writing prophets, Hosea used his own experience as a symbolic representation of God and Israel: God the husband, Israel the wife. Hosea's wife left him to go with other men; Israel left the Lord to go with false gods. Hosea searched for his wife, found her and brought her back; God would not abandon Israel and brought them back even though they had forsaken him.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Book of Hosea was a severe warning to the northern kingdom against the growing idolatry being practiced there; the book was a dramatic call to repentance. Christians extend the analogy of Hosea to Christ and the church: Christ the husband,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bride_of_Christ" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Bride of Christ">his church the bride</a>. Christians see in this book a comparable call to the church not to forsake the Lord Jesus Christ. Christians also take the buying back of Gomer as the redemptive qualities of Jesus Christ's sacrifice on the cross.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Other preachers, like Charles Spurgeon, saw Hosea as a striking presentation of the mercy of God in his sermon on Hosea 1:7 titled The LORD's Own Salvation. "But I will have mercy upon the house of Judah, and will save them by the Lord their God, and will not save them by bow, nor by sword, nor by battle, by horses, nor by horsemen." – Hosea 1:7 in his sermon NO. 2057, December 16TH, 1888.</div>
<h1 class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" lang="en" style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: none; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 1.8em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 0px 0px 0.25em; overflow: visible; padding: 0px;">

For other uses, see&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Horus (disambiguation)">Horus (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<table class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-infobox" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(162 , 169 , 177); clear: right; color: black; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 12.32px; line-height: 1.5em; margin: 0.5em 0px 0.5em 1em; padding: 0.2em; width: 22em;"><tbody>
<tr><th colspan="2" style="background-color: rgb(222 , 205 , 135); font-size: 15.4px; text-align: center; vertical-align: top;">Horus</th></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align: center; vertical-align: top;"><span style="font-size: 13.552px;"><b>God of the sky and kingship</b></span></td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align: center; vertical-align: top;"><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-image" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Horus_standing.svg" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank"><img alt="Horus standing.svg" height="503" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Horus_standing.svg/220px-Horus_standing.svg.png" style="border: 0px; vertical-align: middle;" width="220" /></a><br />
<div>
Horus was often the ancient Egyptians' national&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutelary_deity" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Tutelary deity">tutelary deity</a>. He was usually depicted as a falcon-headed man wearing the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pschent" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Pschent">pschent</a></i>, or a red and white crown, as a symbol of kingship over the entire kingdom of Egypt.</div>
</td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Major cult center</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edfu" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Edfu">Edfu</a></td></tr>

<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Consort</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serket" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Serket">Serket</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Elder),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hathor" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hathor">Hathor</a>(in one version)</td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Offspring</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imset" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Imset">Imset</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hapi_(Son_of_Horus)" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hapi (Son of Horus)">Hapi</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duamutef" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Duamutef">Duamutef</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qebehsenuef" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Qebehsenuef">Qebehse<wbr></wbr>nuef</a>&nbsp;(as Haroeris),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ihy" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Ihy">Ihy</a></td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Parents</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a></td></tr>
<tr><th scope="row" style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">Siblings</th><td style="vertical-align: top;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nephthys" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Nephthys">Nephthys</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Elder),&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anubis" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Anubis">Anubis</a>&nbsp;(as Horus the Younger)</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Horus</b>&nbsp;is one of the most significant&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_deities" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Egyptian deities">ancient Egyptian deities</a>. He was worshipped from at least the late&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prehistoric_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Prehistoric Egypt">prehistoric Egypt</a>&nbsp;until the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt_(Roman_province)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egypt (Roman province)">Roman Egypt</a>. Different forms of Horus are recorded in history and these are treated as distinct gods by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptology" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egyptology">Egyptologists</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;These various forms may possibly be different perceptions of the same multi-layered deity in which certain attributes or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syncretism" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a>&nbsp;relationships are emphasized, not necessarily in opposition but complementary to one another, consistent with how the Ancient Egyptians viewed the multiple facets of reality.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup>&nbsp;He was most often depicted as a falcon, most likely a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanner_falcon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lanner falcon">lanner falcon</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peregrine_falcon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Peregrine falcon">peregrine falcon</a>, or as a man with a falcon head.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The earliest recorded form of Horus is the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutelary_deity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Tutelary deity">tutelary deity</a>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>, who is the first known national god, specifically related to the king who in time came to be regarded as a manifestation of Horus in life and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Osiris">Osiris</a>&nbsp;in death.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;The most commonly encountered family relationship describes Horus as the son of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Isis">Isis</a>&nbsp;and Osiris, and he plays a key role in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osiris_myth" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Osiris myth">Osiris myth</a>&nbsp;as Osiris's heir and the rival to&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, the murderer of Osiris. In another tradition&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hathor" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hathor">Hathor</a>&nbsp;is regarded as his mother and sometimes as his wife.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-oxford_1-2" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-oxford-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>Horus served many functions, most notably being a god of the sky, war and hunting.</div>

<tr><th style="background: navajowhite; border-bottom: 1px solid peru; padding: 0.5em;">ḥr "Horus"<br />
in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">hieroglyphs</a></th></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus is recorded in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">Egyptian hieroglyphs</a>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<i>ḥr.w</i>&nbsp;"Falcon"; the pronunciation has been reconstructed as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">ħaːruw</span>. Additional meanings are thought to have been "the distant one" or "one who is above, over".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup>&nbsp;As the language changed over time, it appeared in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coptic_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Coptic language">Coptic</a>&nbsp;dialects variously as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">hoːɾ</span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">ħoːɾ</span>&nbsp;and was adopted into&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek">ancient Greek</a>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<span lang="grc">Ὧρος</span>&nbsp;<i>Hōros</i>&nbsp;(pronounce<wbr></wbr>d at the time as&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">hoːɾos</span>). It also survives in Late Egyptian and Coptic&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theophoric_name" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Theophoric name">theophoric names</a>&nbsp;such as&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harsiese_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Harsiese (disambiguation)">Har-si-ese</a>&nbsp;"Horus, Son of Isis".</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Nekheny may have been another falcon god worshipped at&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekhen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nekhen">Nekhen</a>, city of the falcon, with whom Horus was identified from early on.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus may be shown as a falcon on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narmer_Palette" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Narmer Palette">Narmer Palette</a>, dating from about the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/31st_century_BC" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="31st century BC">31st century BC</a>.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em;">

Horus was born to the goddess Isis after she retrieved all the dismembered body parts of her murdered husband Osiris, except his&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_penis#Object_of_worship" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Human penis">penis</a>, which was thrown into the Nile and eaten by a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catfish" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Catfish">catfish</a>,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>'s account used her magic powers to resurrect Osiris and fashion a golden&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phallus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Phallus">phallus</a><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-9" style="font-size: 11.2px; <div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Once Isis knew she was pregnant with Horus, she fled to the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nile_Delta" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nile Delta">Nile Delta</a>&nbsp;marshlands to hide from her brother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, who jealously killed Osiris and who she knew would want to kill their son.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-World_mythology_10-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-World_mythology-10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[10]</a></sup>&nbsp;There Isis bore a divine son, Horus.</div>

<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Sky_god">Sky god</span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Since Horus was said to be the sky, he was considered to also contain the sun and moon.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;It became said<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (January 2016)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;that the sun was his right eye and the moon his left, and that they traversed the sky when he, a falcon, flew across it. Later, the reason that the moon was not as bright as the sun was explained by a tale, known as&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Contendings_of_Horus_and_Seth" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Contendings of Horus and Seth">The Contendings of Horus and Seth</a></i>. In this tale, it was said that Set, the patron of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>, and Horus, the patron of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Egypt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lower Egypt">Lower Egypt</a>, had battled for Egypt brutally, with neither side victorious, until eventually the gods sided with Horus.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
As Horus was the ultimate victor he became known as&nbsp;<i>ḥr.w wr</i>&nbsp;"Horus the Great", but more usually translated "Horus the Elder". In the struggle, Set had lost a testicle, explaining why the desert, which Set represented, is infertile. Horus' left eye had also been gouged out, then a new eye was created by part of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khonsu" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Khonsu">Khonsu</a>, the moon god, and was replaced.</div>

The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eye_of_Horus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Eye of Horus">Eye of Horus</a>&nbsp;is an ancient Egyptian symbol of protection and royal power from deities, in this case from Horus or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ra" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ra">Ra</a>. The symbol is seen on images of Horus' mother, Isis, and on other deities associated with her. In the Egyptian language, the word for this symbol was "wedjat" (<i>wɟt</i>).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-13" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-14" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-14" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[14]</a></sup>It was the eye of one of the earliest of Egyptian deities,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wadjet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wadjet">Wadjet</a>, who later became associated with&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bastet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Bastet">Bastet</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mut" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mut">Mut</a>, and Hathor as well. Wadjet was a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_deity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Solar deity">solar deity</a>&nbsp;and this symbol began as her all-seeing eye. In early artwork, Hathor is also depicted with this eye.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-15" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-15" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[15]</a></sup>&nbsp;Funerary amulets were often made in the shape of the Eye of Horus. The Wedjat or Eye of Horus is "the central element" of seven "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Gold">gold</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faience" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Faience">faience</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnelian" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Carnelian">carnelian</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lapis_lazuli" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lapis lazuli"><wbr></wbr>lapis lazuli</a>" bracelets found on the mummy of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoshenq_II" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Shoshenq II">Shoshenq II</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Silverman_16-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-Silverman-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;The Wedjat "was intended to protect the king [here] in the afterlife"<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Silverman_16-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-Silverman-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;and to ward off evil. Egyptian and Near Eastern sailors would frequently paint the symbol on the bow of their vessel to ensure safe sea travel.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-17" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[17]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Conflict_between_Horus_and_Set">Conflict between Horus and Set</span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tright" style="clear: right; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbinner" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); font-size: 13.16px; min-width: 100px; overflow: hidden; padding: 3px; text-align: center; width: 222px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-image" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank"><img alt="" class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbimage" height="125" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg/220px-Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="background-color: rgb(255 , 255 , 255); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); vertical-align: middle;" width="220" /></a><br />
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbcaption" style="border: 0px; font-size: 12.3704px; line-height: 1.4em; padding: 3px; text-align: left;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-magnify" style="float: right; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 0px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-internal" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Egypte_louvre_091_faucon.jpg" style="color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128); display: block; height: 11px; overflow: hidden; text-indent: 15px; white-space: nowrap; width: 15px;" target="_blank" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Horus,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvre" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Louvre">Louvre</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shen_ring" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Shen ring">Shen rings</a>&nbsp;in his grasp</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Horus was told by his mother, Isis, to protect the people of Egypt from&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_(deity)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Set (deity)">Set</a>, the god of the desert, who had killed Horus' father, Osiris.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-19" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-20" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup>&nbsp;Horus had many battles with Set, not only to avenge his father, but to choose the rightful ruler of Egypt. In these battles, Horus came to be associated with Lower Egypt, and became its patron.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
According to&nbsp;<i>The Contendings of Horus and Seth</i>, Set is depicted as trying to prove his dominance by seducing Horus and then having&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_intercourse" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Sexual intercourse">sexual intercourse</a>&nbsp;with him. However, Horus places his hand between his thighs and catches Set's&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Semen">semen</a>, then subsequently throws it in the river so that he may not be said to have been inseminated by Set. Horus then deliberately spreads his own semen on some&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lettuce" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lettuce">lettuce</a>, which was Set's favorite food. After Set had eaten the lettuce, they went to the gods to try to settle the argument over the rule of Egypt. The gods first listened to Set's claim of dominance over Horus, and call his semen forth, but it answered from the river, invalidating his claim. Then, the gods listened to Horus' claim of having dominated Set, and call his semen forth, and it answered from inside Set.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
gyptologists have often tried to connect the conflict between the two gods with political events early in Egypt's history or prehistory. The cases in which the combatants divide the kingdom, and the frequent association of the paired Horus and Set with the union of Upper and Lower Egypt, suggest that the two deities represent some kind of division within the country. Egyptian tradition and archaeological evidence indicate that Egypt was united at the beginning of its history when an Upper Egyptian kingdom, in the south, conquered Lower Egypt in the north. The Upper Egyptian rulers called themselves "followers of Horus", and Horus became the tutelary deity of the unified nation and its kings.&nbsp;</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Greek form of&nbsp;<b>Her-ur</b>&nbsp;(or&nbsp;<b>Har wer</b>) is&nbsp;<b>Haroeris</b>. Other variants include&nbsp;<b>Hor Merti</b>&nbsp;'Horus of the two eyes' and&nbsp;<b>Horkhenti Irti</b>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-29" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horus#cite_note-29" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[29]</a></sup></div>

<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Homer</b>&nbsp;(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient&nbsp;Greek</a>:&nbsp;<span lang="grc">Ὅμηρος</span>&nbsp;<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Help:IPA for Greek">[<wbr></wbr>hómɛːros]</a></span>,&nbsp;<i>Hómēros</i>) is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odyssey" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odyssey">Odyssey</a></i>, two epic poems which are the central works of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_literature" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ancient Greek literature">ancient Greek literature</a>. The&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;is set during the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>, the ten-year siege of the city of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Troy">Troy</a>&nbsp;by a coalition of Greek states. It focuses on a quarrel between King&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agamemnon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Agamemnon">Agamemnon</a>&nbsp;and the warrior&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>&nbsp;lasting a few weeks during the last year of the war. The&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;focuses on the journey home of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odysseus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>, king of Ithaca, after the fall of Troy.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Question" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Question">Homeric Question</a>—by whom, when, where and under what circumstances were the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;composed<wbr></wbr>—continues to be debated. Broadly speaking, modern scholarly opinion falls into two groups. One holds that most of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and (according to some) the&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;are the works of a single poet of genius. The other considers the Homeric poems to be the result of a process of working and re-working by many contributors, and that "Homer" is best seen as a label for an entire tradition.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-bgr_3-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-bgr-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;It is generally accepted that the poems were composed at some point around the late 8th or early 7th century&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Era" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Common Era">BCE</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup>&nbsp;The poems are in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Greek">Homeric Greek</a>, also known as Epic Greek, a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Literary language">literary language</a>&nbsp;which shows a mixture of features of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ionic_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ionic Greek">Ionic</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeolic_Greek" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Aeolic Greek">Aeolic</a>&nbsp;dialects from different centuries; the predominant influence is Eastern Ionic.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[6]</a></sup>&nbsp;Most researchers believe that the poems were originally transmitted orally.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px;
