line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup>&nbsp;These stories were incorporated into the various "lives of Homer",<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-20" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup>&nbsp;"compiled from the Alexandrian period onwards".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Kirk190_21-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-Kirk190-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup></div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Works_attributed_to_Homer">Works attributed to Homer</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Homer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Works attributed to Homer">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Greeks of the sixth and early fifth centuries BCE understood by the works of "Homer", generally, "the whole body of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_poetry" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epic poetry">heroic tradition</a>&nbsp;as embodied in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexameter" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hexameter">hexameter</a>&nbsp;verse".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-66" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-66" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[66]</a></sup>&nbsp;The entire&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_Cycle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epic Cycle">Epic Cycle</a>&nbsp;was included. The genre included further poems on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>, such as the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Iliad" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Little Iliad">Little Iliad</a></i>, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nostoi" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nostoi">Nostoi</a></i>, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cypria" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Cypria">Cypria</a></i>, and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epigoni_(epic)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epigoni (epic)">Epigoni</a></i>, as well as the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thebes,_Greece" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thebes, Greece">Theban</a>&nbsp;poems about&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oedipus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Oedipus">Oedipus</a>&nbsp;and his sons. Other works, such as the corpus of&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeric_Hymns" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homeric Hymns">Homeric Hymns</a></i>, the comic mini-epic&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batrachomyomachia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Batrachomyomachia">Batrachomyomachia</a></i>&nbsp;("<wbr></wbr>The Frog-Mouse War"), and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margites" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Margites">Margites</a></i>, were also attributed to him. Two other poems, the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capture_of_Oechalia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Capture of Oechalia">Capture of Oechalia</a></i>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phocais" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Phocais">Phocais</a></i>, were also assigned Homeric authorship.</div>

</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>&nbsp;remarks in his&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poetics_(Aristotle)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Poetics (Aristotle)">Poetics</a></i>&nbsp;that Homer was unique among the poets of his time, focusing on a single unified theme or action in the epic cycle.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-94" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-94" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[94]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The cardinal qualities of the style of Homer are well articulated by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Arnold" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Matthew Arnold">Matthew Arnold</a>:</div>
<blockquote style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 1em 0px; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px 40px;">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
[T]he translator of Homer should above all be penetrated by a sense of four qualities of his author:—that he is eminently rapid; that he is eminently plain and direct, both in the evolution of his thought and in the expression of it, that is, both in his syntax and in his words; that he is eminently plain and direct in the substance of his thought, that is, in his matter and ideas; and finally, that he is eminently noble.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-95" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer#cite_note-95" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[95]</a></sup></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
One often finds books of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;cited by the corresponding letter of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_alphabet" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Greek alphabet">Greek alphabet</a>, with upper-case letters referring to a book number of the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;and lower-case letters referring to the&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>. Thus Ξ 200 would be shorthand for&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;book 14, line 200, while ξ 200 would be&nbsp;<i>Odyssey</i>&nbsp;14.200. The following table presents this system of numeration:</div>

color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Epic poem">epic poem</a>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dactylic_hexameter" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Dactylic hexameter">dactylic hexameter</a>, traditionally attributed to&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer">Homer</a>. Set during the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>, the ten-year&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Siege">siege</a>&nbsp;of the city of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Troy">Troy</a>&nbsp;(Ilium) by a coalition of Greek states, it tells of the battles and events during the weeks of a quarrel between King&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agamemnon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Agamemnon">Agamemnon</a>&nbsp;and the warrior&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>.</div>

<div>
<h4 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Divine_Intervention">Divine Intervention</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Divine Intervention">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h4>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Some scholars believe that the gods may have intervened in the mortal world because of quarrels they may have had among each other.&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer">Homer</a>&nbsp;interprets the world at this time by using the passion and emotion of the gods to be determining factors of what happens on the human level.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-:0_15-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-:0-15" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[15]</a></sup>&nbsp;An example of one of these relationships in the&nbsp;<i>Iliad</i>&nbsp;occurs between&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Athena">Athena</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hera">Hera</a>, and Aphrodite. In the final book of the poem Homer writes, "He offended Athena and Hera-both goddesses."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-:1_16-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-:1-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;Athena and Hera are envious of Aphrodite because of a beauty pageant on Mount Olympus in which&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Paris (mythology)">Paris</a>&nbsp;chose Aphrodite to be the most beautiful goddess over both Hera and Athena.&nbsp;</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Nostos">Nostos</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Nostos">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nostos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nostos">Nostos</a></i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">νόστος</span>, "homecoming") occurs seven times in the poem.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-17" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[17]</a></sup>&nbsp;Thematically, the concept of homecoming is much explored in Ancient Greek literature, especially in the post-war homeward fortunes experienced by the Atreidae (Agamemnon and Menelaus), and Odysseus (see the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odyssey" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odyssey">Odyssey</a></i>). Thus,&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>&nbsp;is impossible without sacking Troy—King Agamemnon's motive for winning, at any cost.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Kleos">Kleos</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Kleos">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Kleos">Kleos</a></i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">κλέος</span>, "glory, fame") is the concept of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glory" style="background-image: none; color: #663366;" target="_blank" title="wikt:glory">glory</a>&nbsp;earned in heroic battle.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-18" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-18" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[18]</a></sup>&nbsp;For most of the Greek invaders of Troy, notably&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odysseus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>,&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>&nbsp;is earned in a victorious&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>(homecoming). Yet, Achilles must choose only one of the two rewards, either&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-19" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup>&nbsp;In Book IX (IX.410–16), he poignantly tells Agamemnon's envoys—Odysseus, Phoenix, Ajax—begging his reinstatement to battle about having to choose between two fates (<span lang="grc">διχθαδίας κήρας</span>, 9.411).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-autogenerated1_20-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-autogenerated1-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The passage reads:</div>
<table style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin-left: 3em;"><tbody>
<tr><td><div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-poem" lang="">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<span lang="grc">μήτηρ γάρ τέ μέ φησι θεὰ Θέτις ἀργυρόπεζα (410)<br />διχθαδίας κῆρας φερέμεν θανάτοιο τέλος δέ.<br />εἰ μέν κ' αὖθι μένων Τρώων πόλιν ἀμφιμάχωμαι,<br />ὤλετο μέν μοι νόστος, ἀτὰρ κλέος ἄφθιτον ἔσται<br />εἰ δέ κεν οἴκαδ' ἵκωμι φίλην ἐς πατρίδα γαῖαν,<br />ὤλετό μοι κλέος ἐσθλόν, ἐπὶ δηρὸν δέ μοι αἰὼν (415)<br />ἔσσεται, οὐδέ κέ μ' ὦκα τέλος θανάτοιο κιχείη.</span><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</td><td style="padding-left: 2em;"><div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-poem">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
For my mother&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetis" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Thetis">Thetis</a>&nbsp;the goddess of silver feet tells me<br />
I carry two sorts of destiny toward the day of my death. Either,<br />
if I stay here and fight beside the city of the Trojans,<br />
my return home is gone, but my glory shall be everlasting;<br />
but if I return home to the beloved land of my fathers,<br />
the excellence of my glory is gone, but there will be a long life<br />
left for me, and my end in death will not come to me quickly.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</td></tr>
<tr style="font-size: 12.32px; vertical-align: top;"><td></td><td style="padding-left: 2em;">—Translated by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_Lattimore" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Richmond Lattimore">Richmond Lattimore</a></td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
In forgoing his&nbsp;<i>nostos</i>, he will earn the greater reward of&nbsp;<i>kleos aphthiton</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">κλέος ἄφθιτον</span>, "fame imperishable").<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-autogenerated1_20-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-autogenerated1-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup>&nbsp;In the poem,&nbsp;<i>aphthiton</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">ἄφθιτον</span>, "imperishable") occurs five other times,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-23" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup>&nbsp;each occurrence denotes an object: Agamemnon's sceptre, the wheel of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebe_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebe (mythology)">Hebe</a>'s chariot, the house of Poseidon, the throne of Zeus, the house of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hephaestus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hephaestus">Hephaestus</a>. Translator&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_Lattimore" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Richmond Lattimore">Lattimore</a>&nbsp;renders&nbsp;<i>k<wbr></wbr>leos aphthiton</i>&nbsp;as&nbsp;<i>forever immortal</i>&nbsp;and as&nbsp;<i>forever imperishable</i>—connoting Achilles's mortality by underscoring his greater reward in returning to battle Troy.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Kleos is often given visible representation by the prizes won in battle. When Agamemnon takes Briseis from Achilles, he takes away a portion of the kleos he had earned.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Achilles' shield, crafted by Hephaestus and given to him by his mother Thetis, bears an image of stars in the centre. The stars conjure profound images of the place of a single man, no matter how heroic, in the perspective of the entire cosmos.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Tim.C3.AA">Timê</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Timê">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Akin to&nbsp;<i>kleos</i>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<i>timê</i>&nbsp;(<span lang="grc">τιμή</span>, "respect, honor"), the concept denoting the respectability an honorable man accrues with accomplishment (cultural, political, martial), per his station in life. In Book I, the Greek troubles begin with King Agamemnon's dishonorable, unkingly behavior—first, by threatening the priest Chryses (1.11), then, by aggravating them in disrespecting Achilles, by confiscating Briseis from him (1.171). The warrior's consequent rancor against the dishonorable king ruins the Greek military cause.</div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Wrath">Wrath</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iliad&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Wrath">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumb gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-tright" style="clear: right; float: right; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 0.5em 0px 1.3em 1.4em; width: auto;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbinner" style="background-color: rgb(248 , 249 , 250); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); font-size: 13.16px; min-width: 100px; overflow: hidden; padding: 3px; text-align: center; width: 252px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-image" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wrath_of_Achilles2.jpg" style="background: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank"><img alt="" class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbimage" height="195" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Wrath_of_Achilles2.jpg/250px-Wrath_of_Achilles2.jpg" style="background-color: rgb(255 , 255 , 255); border: 1px solid rgb(200 , 204 , 209); vertical-align: middle;" width="250" /></a><br />
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-thumbcaption" style="border: 0px; font-size: 12.3704px; line-height: 1.4em; padding: 3px; text-align: left;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-magnify" style="float: right; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 0px;">
<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-internal" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wrath_of_Achilles2.jpg" style="color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128); display: block; height: 11px; overflow: hidden; text-indent: 15px; white-space: nowrap; width: 15px;" target="_blank" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<i>The Wrath of Achilles</i>&nbsp;(1819), by Michel Drolling.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The poem's initial word,&nbsp;<span lang="grc">μῆνιν</span>&nbsp;(<i>mēnin</i>,&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accusative" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Accusative">accusative</a><wbr></wbr>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<span lang="grc">μῆνις</span>,&nbsp;<i>mēnis</i>, "wrath, rage, fury"), establishes the&nbsp;<i>Iliad's</i>&nbsp;principal theme: The "Wrath of Achilles".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup>&nbsp;His personal rage and wounded soldier's vanity propel the story: the Greeks' faltering in battle, the slayings of Patroclus and Hector, and the fall of Troy. In Book I, the Wrath of Achilles first emerges in the Achilles-convoked meeting, between the Greek kings and the seer&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calchas" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Calchas">Calchas</a>. King Agamemnon dishonours Chryses, the Trojan priest of Apollo, by refusing with a threat the restitution of his daughter, Chryseis—despite the proffered ransom of "gifts beyond count".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-25" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;The insulted priest prays his god's help, and a nine-day rain of divine plague arrows falls upon the Greeks. Moreover, in that meeting, Achilles accuses Agamemnon of being "greediest for gain of all men".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup>&nbsp;To that, Agamemnon replies:</div>
<blockquote style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; margin: 1em 0px; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px 40px;">
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
But here is my threat to you.<br />
Even as Phoibos Apollo is taking away my Chryseis.<br />
I shall convey her back in my own ship, with my own<br />
followers; but I shall take the fair-cheeked Briseis,<br />
your prize, I myself going to your shelter, that you may learn well<br />
how much greater I am than you, and another man may shrink back<br />
from likening himself to me and contending against me.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-27" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iliad#cite_note-27" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[27]</a></sup></div>
</blockquote>

<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Homer Jay Simpson</b>&nbsp;is a fictional character and the main protagonist of the American animated television series&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i>&nbsp;as the patriarch of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simpson_family" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Simpson family">eponymous family</a>. He is voiced by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Castellaneta" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Dan Castellaneta">Dan Castellaneta</a>&nbsp;and first appeared on television, along with the rest of his family, in&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tracey_Ullman_Show" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Tracey Ullman Show">The Tracey Ullman Show</a></i>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons_shorts" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons shorts">short</a>&nbsp;"<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Night_(The_Simpsons_short)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Good Night (The Simpsons short)">Good Night</a>" on April 19, 1987. Homer was created and designed by cartoonist&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Groening" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Matt Groening">Matt Groening</a>&nbsp;while he was waiting in the lobby of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_L._Brooks" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="James L. Brooks">James L. Brooks</a>' office. Groening had been called to pitch a series of shorts based on his comic strip&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_in_Hell" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Life in Hell">Life in Hell</a></i>&nbsp;but instead decided to create a new set of characters. He named the character after his father, Homer Groening. After appearing for three seasons on&nbsp;<i>The Tracey Ullman Show</i>, the Simpson family got their own series on&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>&nbsp;that debuted December 17, 1989.</div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Homer and his wife&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marge_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Marge Simpson">Marge</a>&nbsp;have three children:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bart_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Bart Simpson">Bart</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lisa Simpson">Lisa</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maggie_Simpson" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Maggie Simpson">Maggie</a>. As the family's provider, he works at the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield_(The_Simpsons)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Springfield (The Simpsons)">Springfield Nuclear Power Plant</a>&nbsp;as safety inspector. Homer embodies several American&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Working class">working class</a>&nbsp;stereotypes: he is a crude, bald, obese, short-tempered, neglectful of the rules, clumsy, lazy, heavy drinking, ignorant and idiotic person; however, he is essentially a decent man and fiercely devoted to his family. Despite the suburban&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue-collar_worker" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Blue-collar worker">blue-collar</a>&nbsp;routine of his life, he has had a number of remarkable experiences.</div>
<div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">

color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homer">Homer</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-americasfirstfamily_14-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;Very little else of Homer's character was based on him, and to prove that the meaning behind Homer's name was not significant, Groening later named his own son Homer.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-17" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-18" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[18]</a></sup>&nbsp;According to Groening, "Homer originated with my goal to both amuse my real father, and just annoy him a little bit. My father was an athletic, creative, intelligent filmmaker and writer, and the only thing he had in common with Homer was a love of donuts."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-EW_2010_19-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-EW_2010-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup>&nbsp;Although Groening has stated in several interviews that Homer was named after his father, he also claimed in several 1990 interviews that a character in the 1939&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathanael_West" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nathanael West">Nathanael West</a>&nbsp;novel&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Day_of_the_Locust" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Day of the Locust">The Day of the Locust</a></i>&nbsp;was the inspiration for naming Homer.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner200478.E2.80.9379_1-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; Moose</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_the_Flying_Squirrel" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Rocky the Flying Squirrel">Rocket J. Squirrel</a>&nbsp;from&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Rocky_and_Bullwinkle_Show" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show">The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show</a></i>, who got their middle initial from&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jay_Ward" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Jay Ward">Jay Ward</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-23" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Homer made his debut with the rest of the Simpson family on April 19, 1987, in&nbsp;<i>The Tracey Ullman Show</i>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons_shorts" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Simpsons shorts">short</a>&nbsp;"<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Night_(The_Simpsons_short)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Good Night (The Simpsons short)">Good Night</a>".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichmond_.26_Coffman199714_25-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichmond_.26_Coffman199714-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;In 1989, the shorts were adapted into&nbsp;<i>The Simpsons</i>, a half-hour series airing on the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox Broadcasting Company</a>. Homer and the Simpson family remained the main characters on this new show.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-D.27oh.21">D'oh!</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Homer_Simpson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: D'oh!">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
Main article:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%27oh!" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="D'oh!">D'oh!</a></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Homer's catchphrase, the annoyed grunt "D'oh!", is typically uttered when he injures himself, realizes that he has done something stupid, or when something bad has happened or is about to happen to him. During the voice recording session for a&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tracey_Ullman_Show" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Tracey Ullman Show">Tracey Ullman Show</a></i>&nbsp;short, Homer was required to utter what was written in the script as an "annoyed grunt". Dan Castellaneta rendered it as a drawn out "d'ooooooh". This was inspired by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Finlayson_(actor)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="James Finlayson (actor)">Jimmy Finlayson</a>, the mustachioed Scottish actor who appeared in 33&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurel_and_Hardy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Laurel and Hardy">Laurel and Hardy</a>films. Finlayson had used the term as a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minced_oath" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Minced oath">minced oath</a>&nbsp;to stand in for the word "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damnation" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Damnation">Damn</a>!"&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Groening" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Matt Groening">Matt Groening</a>&nbsp;felt that it would better suit the timing of animation if it were spoken faster. Castellaneta then shortened it to a quickly uttered "D'oh!"<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-herald_125-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-herald-125" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[125]</a></sup>&nbsp;The first intentional use of D'oh! occurred in the Ullman short "The Krusty the Clown Show"<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-herald_125-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-herald-125" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[125]</a></sup>&nbsp;(1989), and its first usage in the series was in the series premiere, "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simpsons_Roasting_on_an_Open_Fire" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire">Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire</a>".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-doh_126-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-doh-126" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[126]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
"D'oh!" was first added to&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_Dictionary_of_English" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Oxford Dictionary of English">The New Oxford Dictionary of English</a></i>&nbsp;in 1998. It is defined as an interjection "used to comment on an action perceived as foolish or stupid".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-127" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-127" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[127]</a></sup>&nbsp;In 2001, "D'oh!" was added to the&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i>, without the apostrophe ("Doh!").<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-128" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-128" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[128]</a></sup>&nbsp;The definition of the word is "expressing frustration at the realization that things have turned out badly or not as planned, or that one has just said or done something foolish".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-129" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-129" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[129]</a></sup>&nbsp;In 2006, "D'oh!" was placed in sixth position on&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Land" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="TV Land">TV Land</a>'s list of the 100 greatest television catchphrases.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-130" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-130" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[130]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-131" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-131" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[131]</a></sup>&nbsp;"D'oh!<wbr></wbr>" is also included in&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Oxford_Dictionary_of_Quotations" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations">The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations</a></i>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-132" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_Simpson#cite_note-132" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[132]</a></sup></div>

<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
A&nbsp;<b>home</b>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<b>domicile</b>&nbsp;is a dwelling-place used as a permanent or semi-permanent residence for an&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Person" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Person">individual</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Family">family</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Household" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Household">househo<wbr></wbr>ld</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longhouse" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Longhouse">several families in a tribe</a>. It is often a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="House">house</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apartment" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Apartment">apartment</a>, or other&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Building" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Building">building</a>, or alternatively a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_home" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mobile home">mobile home</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houseboat" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Houseboat">houseboat</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yurt" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Yurt">yurt</a>&nbsp;or any other portable shelter. Homes typically provide areas and facilities for sleeping, preparing food, eating and hygiene. Larger groups may live in a&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nursing_home" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nursing home">nursing home</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphanage" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Orphanage">children's home</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convent" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Convent">convent</a>&nbsp;or any similar institution. A&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_(buildings)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homestead (buildings)">homestead</a>&nbsp;also includes agricultural land and facilities for&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domesticated_animals" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Domesticated animals">domesticated animals</a>. Where more secure&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwelling" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Dwelling">dwellings</a>&nbsp;are not available, people may live in the informal and sometimes illegal&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shack" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Shack">shacks</a>&nbsp;found in&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slums" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Slums">slums</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanty_town" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Shanty town">shanty towns</a>. More generally, "home" may be considered to be a geographic area, such as a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Town">town</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Village" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Village">village</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suburb" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Suburb">suburb</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="City">city</a>, or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Country">country</a>.</div>
<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Transitory accommodation in a treatment facility for a few weeks is not normally considered permanent enough to replace a more stable location as 'home'.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;In 2005, 100 million people worldwide were estimated to be&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homelessness">homeless</a>.</div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
A&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terraced_house" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Terraced house">terraced house</a><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[a]</a></sup>&nbsp;is a style of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium-density_housing" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Medium-density housing">medium-density housing</a>&nbsp;where a row of identical or mirror-image houses share side walls, while&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-detached" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Semi-detached">semi-detached</a>&nbsp;housing consists of pairs of houses built side-by-side or (less commonly) back-to-back,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-6" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup>&nbsp;sharing a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_wall" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Party wall">party wall</a>&nbsp;and with mirrored layouts.</div>
<div>

<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Psychological_significance">Psychological significance</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Home&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Psychological significance">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
A home is generally a place that is close to the heart of the owner, and can become a prized possession. It has been argued that psychologically "<i>The strongest sense of home commonly coincides geographically with a dwelling. Usually the sense of home attenuates as one moves away from that point, but it does not do so in a fixed or regular way.</i>"<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-12" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-12" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[11]</a></sup>Since it can be said that humans are generally creatures of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habituation" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Habituation">habit</a>, the state of a person's home has been known to physiologically influence their&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Behavior">behavior</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Emotion">emotions</a>, and overall&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_health" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mental health">mental health</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-13" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[12]</a></sup>&nbsp;People may become&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homesickness" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Homesickness">homesick</a>&nbsp;when they leave their home over an extended period of time. Places like homes can trigger self-reflection, thoughts about who someone is or used to be or who they might become.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;These types of reflections also occur in places where there is a collective historical identity, such as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Battle of Gettysburg">Gettysburg</a>or&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_Zero" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ground Zero">Ground Zero</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-14" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-14" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">

line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home#cite_note-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup>&nbsp;and "<i>home is where you hang your hat</i>".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-18" style="font-size: 11.2px;
