<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-content-text" lang="en" style="direction: ltr;">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-parser-output">
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-size: 0.875em; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
For other uses, see&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Holy Spirit (disambiguation)">Holy Spirit (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Holy Spirit</b>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<b>Holy Ghost</b>&nbsp;is a term found in&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_translations_of_the_Bible" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="English translations of the Bible">English translations of the Bible</a>&nbsp;that is understood differently among the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Levison2002_1-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Levison2002-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-CanerCaner_2-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-CanerCaner-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup>&nbsp;Holy Spirit is stated to be "a realm beyond the ability of words to properly convey. It must be experienced, realized, kindled within like a holy fire."<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Ragland2003_3-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Ragland2003-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;The term is also used to describe aspects of other religions and belief structures.</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Holy_Spirit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The word "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirit" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Spirit">Spirit</a>" (from the Latin&nbsp;<i>spiritus</i>&nbsp;meaning "breath") appears as either alone or with other words, in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>&nbsp;(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Testament" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a>) and the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Testament" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>. Combinations include expressions such as the "Holy Spirit", "Spirit of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_in_Abrahamic_religions" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="God in Abrahamic religions">God</a>", and in Christianity, "Spirit of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christ_(title)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Christ (title)">Christ</a>".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBultmann2007153_4-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBultmann2007153-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The word Spirit is rendered as רוּחַ (<i>ruach</i>) in Hebrew-language parts of the Old Testament.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Caulley2001_5-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Caulley2001-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup>&nbsp;In&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblical_Aramaic" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Biblical Aramaic">its Aramaic parts</a>, the term is&nbsp;<i>rûacḥ</i>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Levison2009_6-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Levison2009-6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[6]</a></sup>&nbsp;The Greek translation of the Old Testament, the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Septuagint" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a>, translates the word as πνεῦμα (<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneuma" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Pneuma">pneuma</a></i>).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Caulley2001_5-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Caulley2001-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup>&nbsp;This is the same word that is used throughout the New Testament, written originally in Greek.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBultmann2007154_7-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBultmann2007154-7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[7]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The English term "Spirit" comes from its Latin origin,&nbsp;<i>spiritus</i>, which is how the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulgate" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>&nbsp;translates both the Old and New Testament concept.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-8" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-8" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[8]</a></sup>&nbsp;The alternative term, "Holy Ghost", comes from&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Old English">Old English</a>&nbsp;translations of&nbsp;<i>spiritus</i>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-9" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-9" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[9]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Hebrew Bible contains the term "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit_in_Judaism" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Holy Spirit in Judaism">Spirit of God</a>" (<i>ruach hakodesh</i>) in the sense of the might of a unitary&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_in_Judaism" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="God in Judaism">God</a>. This meaning is different from the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Christianity">Christian</a>&nbsp;concept of "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit_in_Christianity" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Holy Spirit in Christianity">Holy Spirit</a>" as one personality of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_in_Christianity" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="God in Christianity">God</a>&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Trinity">Trinity</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-10" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[10]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Hebrew language phrase&nbsp;<i>ruach ha-kodesh</i>&nbsp;(<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebrew" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>: רוח הקודש, "holy spirit" also transliterated&nbsp;<i>ruacḥ ha-qodesh</i>) is a term used in the Hebrew Bible (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanakh" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Tanakh">Tanakh</a>) and Jewish writings to refer to the spirit of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YHWH" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="YHWH">YHWH</a>&nbsp;(רוח יהוה). It literally means "spirit of the holiness" or "spirit of the holy place". The Hebrew terms&nbsp;<i>ruacḥ qodshəka</i>, "thy holy spirit" (רוּחַ קָדְשְׁךָ), and&nbsp;<i>ruacḥ qodshō</i>, "his holy spirit" (רוּחַ קָדְשׁוֹ) also occur (when a possessive suffix is added the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definite_article" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Definite article">definite article</a>&nbsp;is dropped).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The "Holy Spirit" in Judaism generally refers to the divine aspect of prophecy and wisdom. It also refers to the divine force, quality, and influence of the Most High God, over the universe or over his creatures, in given contexts.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Encyclopedia_Judaica_19-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Encyclopedia_Judaica-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
For the large majority of Christians, The Holy Spirit (or Holy Ghost, from Old English&nbsp;<i>gast</i>, "spirit") is the third&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostasis_(philosophy_and_religion)" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Hypostasis (philosophy and religion)">divine person</a>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trinity" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="The Trinity">The Trinity</a>: The "Triune God" manifested as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_the_Father" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="God the Father">Father</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_the_Son" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="God the Son">Son</a>, and Holy Spirit; each aspect itself being God.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Erickson103_21-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Erickson103-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Hammond_22-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Hammond-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[22]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-Systematic_theology_23-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-Systematic_theology-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup>&nbsp;Two symbols from the New Testament canon are associated with the Holy Spirit in Christian&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iconography" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Iconography">iconography</a>: a winged dove, and tongues of fire.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;Each depiction of the Holy Spirit arose from different historical accounts in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Gospel">Gospel</a>&nbsp;narratives; the first being at the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baptism_of_Jesus" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Baptism of Jesus">baptism of Jesus</a>&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_River" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a>&nbsp;where the Holy Spirit was said to descend in the form of a dove as the voice of God the Father spoke as described in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Gospel of Matthew">Matthew</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Gospel of Mark">Mark</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Gospel of Luke">Luke</a>;<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;the second being from the day of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentecost" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, fifty days after&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Easter" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Easter">Pascha</a>&nbsp;where the descent of the Holy Spirit came upon the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apostle_(Christian)" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Apostle (Christian)">Apostles</a>&nbsp;and other followers of&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesus_Christ" style="background-image: none; color: rgb(11 , 0 , 128);" target="_blank" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>.<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Acts+2:1%E2%80%9331:1&amp;version=nrsv" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">2:1–31</a><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup>&nbsp;Called "the unveiled epiphany of God",<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-25" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Spirit#cite_note-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;the Holy Spirit is the one who enabled the proclamation of Jesus Christ, and the power that brought conviction of faith.</div>
<h1 class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-firstHeading" lang="en" style="background-attachment: initial; background-clip: initial; background-image: none; background-origin: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial; background-size: initial; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 1.8em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 0px 0px 0.25em; overflow: visible; padding: 0px;">
Sacred</h1>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-body-content" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-bodyContent" style="line-height: 1.6;">

<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-size: 0.875em; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
For other uses, see&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Sacred (disambiguation)">Sacred (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-size: 0.875em; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
"Holy" and "Sanctity" redirect here. For other uses, see&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Holy (disambiguation)">Holy (disambiguation)</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-disambig" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanctity_(disambiguation)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Sanctity (disambiguation)">Sanctity (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<b>Sacred</b>&nbsp;means revered due to&nbsp;<b>sanctity</b>&nbsp;and is generally the state of being perceived by religious individuals as associated with&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divinity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Divinity">divinity</a>&nbsp;and considered worthy of spiritual respect or devotion; or inspiring&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Awe" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Awe">awe</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverence_(emotion)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Reverence (emotion)">reverence</a>&nbsp;amo<wbr></wbr>ng believers.</div>
<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
From an anthropological or atheistic perspective, the religious view of the sacred is an&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emic_and_etic" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Emic and etic">emic</a>&nbsp;perspective on a culture's collection of thoughts and practices that function as a basis for the community's social structure.</div>
<div style="font-size: 0.875em; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Objects are often considered sacred if used for spiritual purposes, such as the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worship" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Worship">worship</a>&nbsp;or service of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deity" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Deity">gods</a>. The property is often ascribed to objects (a "sacred artifact" that is venerated and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blessing" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Blessing">blessed</a>), or places ("sacred ground").</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sacred&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The word "sacred" descends from the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Latin">Latin</a>&nbsp;<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sacer" style="background-image: none; color: #663366;" target="_blank" title="wikt:sacer">wikt:sacer</a></i>, that is consecrated, or dedicated<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-1" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;to the gods or anything in their power, and to&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_ancient_Roman_religion#sacerdos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Glossary of ancient Roman religion">sacerdos</a></i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_ancient_Roman_religion#sacerdos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Glossary of ancient Roman religion">sanctum</a></i>, set apart.</div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Distinguished_from_.22Holy.22">Distinguished from "Holy"</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sacred&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Distinguished from &quot;Holy&quot;">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-size: 14px; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
Main article:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hallow" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hallow">Hallow</a></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Although there are similarities between the terms "sacred" and "holy" and they are sometimes used interchangeably, there are subtle differences.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-difference_2-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-difference-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup>&nbsp;"Holiness" is generally the term used in relation to persons and relationship, while "sacredness" is used in relation to objects, places, or happenings.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-3" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[3]</a></sup>&nbsp;Thus a saint may be considered as holy, but he is not viewed as sacred. However, there are things that are both holy and sacred such as the holy bible.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-difference_2-1" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-difference-2" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[2]</a></sup></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The English word "holy" dates back to at least the 11th century with the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Old English">Old English</a>&nbsp;word&nbsp;<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C4%81lig" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hālig">hālig</a></i>, an adjective derived from&nbsp;<i>hāl</i>&nbsp;meaning "whole" and used to mean "uninjured, sound, healthy, entire, complete". The Scottish&nbsp;<i>hale</i>&nbsp;("health, happiness and wholeness") is the most complete modern form of this Old English root. The word "holy" in its modern form appears in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wycliffe%27s_Bible" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wycliffe's Bible">Wycliffe's Bible</a>&nbsp;of 1382. In non-specialist contexts, the term "holy" is used in a more general way, to refer to someone or something that is associated with a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divine_grace" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Divine grace">divine power</a>, such as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_water" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Holy water">water</a>&nbsp;used for&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baptism" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Baptism">baptism</a>.</div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
While both words denote something or someone set apart to the worship of God and therefore worthy of respect and in some cases veneration, "holy" (the stronger word) implies an inherent or essential character.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-4" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[4]</a></sup>&nbsp;Holiness originates in God and is communicated to things, places, times, and persons engaged in His Service. Thus Aquinas Thomas defines "holiness" as that virtue by which a man's mind applies itself and all its acts to God; he ranks it among the infused moral virtues, and identifies it with the virtue of religion, but with this difference that, whereas religion is the virtue whereby one offers God due service in the things which pertain to the Divine service, holiness is the virtue by which one makes all one's acts subservient to God. Thus holiness or sanctity is the outcome of sanctification, that Divine act by which God freely justifies a person, and by which He has claimed them for His own.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-5" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-5" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[5]</a></sup></div>
<h2 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 1px solid rgb(162, 169, 177); font-family: &quot;linux libertine&quot;, georgia, times, serif; font-size: 0.875em; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1.3; margin: 1em 0px 0.25em; overflow: hidden; padding: 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Academic_views">Academic views</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-family: sans-serif; font-size: small; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sacred&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Academic views">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h2>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Hierology">Hierology</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sacred&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Hierology">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-hatnote gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-navigation-not-searchable" style="font-size: 14px; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 0.5em; padding-left: 1.6em;">
See also:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierotopy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hierotopy">Hierotopy</a></div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Hierology (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Greek language">Greek</a>&nbsp;ιερος,&nbsp;<i>hieros</i>, "sacred" or "holy", +&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/-logy" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="-logy">-logy</a>) is the study of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_text" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Religious text">sacred literature</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folklore" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Folklore">lore</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-6" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-6" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[6]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-7" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-7" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[7]</a></sup></div>
<h3 style="background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; margin: 0.3em 0px 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0.5em;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Islam">Islam</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sacred&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Islam">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></h3>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
Among the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Names_of_God_in_the_Qur%27an" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Names of God in the Qur'an">names of God in the Qur'an</a>&nbsp;is القدوس (<i>Al-Quddus</i>)&nbsp;: found in&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D59%3Averse%3D23" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">59:23</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114external gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-text" href="http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D62%3Averse%3D1" rel="nofollow" style="color: #663366; padding-right: 13px;" target="_blank">62:1</a>, the closest English translation is "holy" or "sacred". It shares the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-D-%C5%A0" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Q-D-Š">same triliteral Semitic root</a>&nbsp;as the Hebrew&nbsp;<i>kodesh</i>&nbsp;(see below). Another use of the same root is found in the Arabic name for Jerusalem:&nbsp;<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Quds" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Al-Quds">al-Quds</a></i>, "the Holy".</div>
<div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The word حرام&nbsp;<i>(ħarām)</i>, often translated as "prohibited" or "forbidden", is better understood as "sacred" or "sanctuary" in the context of places considered sacred in Islam,&nbsp;<i>e. g.</i>: the&nbsp;<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masjid_al-Haram" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Masjid al-Haram">Masjid al-Haram</a></i>, the Sacred Mosque in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecca" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, constituting the immediate precincts of the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ka%27aba" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ka'aba">Ka'aba</a>;&nbsp;<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haram_(site)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Haram (site)">al-Haramain</a></i>&nbsp;or "the (two) Sanctuaries", a reference to the twin holy cities of Mecca and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medina" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Medina">Medina</a>; and the&nbsp;<i><a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haram_ash-Sharif" style="background-image: none; <div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
The Hebrew word קֹדֶשׁ, transliterated as&nbsp;<i>qodesh</i>, has been used in the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torah" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Torah">Torah</a>&nbsp;to mean set-apartness and separateness as well as holiness and sacredness.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-cite_ref-13" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred#cite_note-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup>&nbsp;The Torah describes the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kohen" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Kohen">Aaronite priests</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levite" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Levite">Levites</a>&nbsp;as being selected by God to perform the Temple services; they, as well, are called "holy." Some<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (September 2011)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup>&nbsp;consider that the Hebrew noun for "holiness,"&nbsp;<i>kedushah</i>&nbsp;(<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebrew_language" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>:&nbsp;<span dir="rtl" lang="he"><wbr></wbr>קדושה</span>‎‎), from the adjective&nbsp;<i>kodesh</i>, "holy," has the connotation of "separateness".<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. <div style="font-size: 14px; line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
However, holiness is not a single state, but contains a broad spectrum. The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mishnah" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Mishnah">Mishnah</a>&nbsp;lists concentric circles of holiness surrounding the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temple_in_Jerusalem" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Temple in Jerusalem">Temple in Jerusalem</a>:&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_of_Holies" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Holy of Holies">Holy of Holies</a>, Temple Sanctuary, Temple Vestibule, Court of Priests, Court of Israelites, Court of Women,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temple_Mount" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>, the walled city of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerusalem" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, all the walled cities of Israel, and the borders of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_of_Israel" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-noprint gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Inline-Template gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-m_-3338996209770952114gmail-Template-Fact" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. <span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">Hera is commonly seen with the animals she considers sacred including the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Cattle">cow</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lion" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Lion">lion</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peafowl" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Peafowl">peacock</a>. <span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">Hera is the daughter of the youngest Titan&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cronus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Cronus">Cronus</a>&nbsp;and his wife, and sister,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhea_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Rhea (mythology)">Rhea</a>. Zeus grew up in secret and when he grew up he tricked his father into regurgitating his siblings, including Hera. Zeus then led the revolt against the Titans, banished them, and divided the dominion over the world with his brothers&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poseidon" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Poseidon">Poseidon</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hades" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hades">Hades</a>.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-22" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-22" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[<wbr></wbr>22]</a></sup></span></div>

<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">Hera was most known as the matron goddess,&nbsp;<i>Hera Teleia</i>; but she presided over weddings as well. In myth and cult, fragmentary references and archaic practices remain of the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred_marriage" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Sacred marriage">sacred marriage</a>&nbsp;of Hera and Zeus,<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-23" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-23" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[23]</a></sup>&nbsp;and at&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plataea" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Plataea">Plataea</a>, there was a sculpture of Hera seated as a bride by&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Callimachus" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Callimachus">Callimachus</a>, as well as the matronly standing Hera.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-24" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-24" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[24]</a></sup></span></div>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">Hera was also worshipped as a&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Virgin">virgin</a>: there was a tradition in&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stymphalia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Stymphalia">Stymphalia</a>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcadia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Arcadia">Arcadia</a>&nbsp;that there had been a&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_Goddess_(Neopaganism)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Triple Goddess (Neopaganism)">triple shrine</a>&nbsp;to Hera the Girl (Παις [Pais]), the Adult Woman (Τελεια [Teleia]), and the Separated (Χήρη [Chḗrē] 'Widowed' or 'Divorced').<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-25" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-25" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[25]</a></sup>&nbsp;In the&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argolid" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Argolid">region around Argos</a>, the temple of Hera in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ermioni" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Ermioni">Hermione</a>&nbsp;near Argos was to Hera the Virgin.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-26" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-26" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[26]</a></sup>&nbsp;At the spring of&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanathos" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Kanathos">Kanathos</a>, close to&nbsp;<a class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-redirect" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nauplia" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Nauplia">Nauplia</a>, Hera renewed her virginity annually, in rites that were not to be spoken of (<i>arrheton</i>).<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-27" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-27" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[27]</a></sup>&nbsp;The Female figure, showing her "Moon" over the lake is also appropriate, as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebe_(mythology)" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hebe (mythology)">Hebe</a>, Hera, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hecate" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Hecate">Hecate</a>; new moon, full moon, and old moon in that order and otherwise personified as the Virgin of spring, The Mother of Summer, and the destroying Crone of Autumn.<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-28" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-28" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[28]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-29" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera#cite_note-29" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[29]</a></sup></span></div>

<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-headline" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-Idiomatic_expressions">Idiomatic expressions</span><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-editsection" style="display: inline-block; font-size: small; font-weight: normal; line-height: 1em; margin-left: 1em; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: nowrap;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-right: 0.25em;">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Head&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Edit section: Idiomatic expressions">edit</a><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mw-editsection-bracket" style="color: rgb(85 , 85 , 85); margin-left: 0.25em;">]</span></span></span></h3>
<div style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0.5em 0px;">
<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">An&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idiom" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Idiom">idiom</a>&nbsp;is a phrase or a fixed expression that has a figurative, or sometimes literal, meaning.</span></div>
<ul style="margin: 0.3em 0px 0px 1.6em; padding: 0px;">
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"To come to a head"&nbsp;– to reach a critical stage and require immediate action<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Dolgopolov_2004_p._104_13-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Dolgopolov_2004_p._104-13" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[13]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"To bite someone's head off"&nbsp;– to criticize someone strongly<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Palmatier_2000_p._24_14-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Palmatier_2000_p._24-14" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[14]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"Can't make head or tail of something"&nbsp;– cannot understand something<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Curtis_2015_p._84_15-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Curtis_2015_p._84-15" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[15]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"A head start"&nbsp;– an early start that provides an advantage over others<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Ammer_2013_p._206_16-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Ammer_2013_p._206-16" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[16]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"Head and shoulders above someone or something"&nbsp;– better than someone or something in some way<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Brenner_2011_p._234_17-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Brenner_2011_p._234-17" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[17]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"To want someone's head on a platter"&nbsp;– to want someone severely punished<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-18" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-18" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[18]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"To bang your head against a brick wall"&nbsp;– to continually try to achieve something without success<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Ayto_2010_p._45_19-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Ayto_2010_p._45-19" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[19]</a></sup></span></li>
<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">"To have one's head in the clouds"&nbsp;– to not pay attention to what is happening around one because one is so absorbed by one's own thoughts<sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-Kirkpatrick_Schwarz_1993_20-0" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-Kirkpatrick_Schwarz_1993-20" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[20]</a></sup><sup class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-reference" id="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-cite_ref-21" style="font-size: 11.2px; line-height: 1; white-space: nowrap;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head#cite_note-21" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank">[21]</a></sup></span></li>
</ul>

<span class="gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-mention-gloss-paren gmail-m_-4078038848446458856gmail-annotation-paren">The head's function and appearance play an analogous role in the etymology of many technical terms.&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cylinder_head" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Cylinder head">Cylinder head</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pothead" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Pothead">pothead</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weatherhead" style="background-image: none; color: #0b0080;" target="_blank" title="Weatherhead">weatherhead</a>&nbsp;are three such examples.</span></div>

<span style="font-size: xx-small;">The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grinch" target="_blank" title="Grinch">Grinch</a>&nbsp;is a bitter, grouchy, cave-dwelling creature with a heart "two sizes too small" who lives on snowy Mount Crumpit, a steep high mountain just north of the town of <b>Who</b>ville, home of the merry and warm-hearted <b>Who</b>s. His only companion is his unloved, but loyal dog, <span style="font-family: arial black, sans-serif;">Max</span>. From his cave, the Grinch can hear the noisy Christmas festivities that take place in <b>Who</b>ville. Annoyed, he decides to stop Christmas from coming by stealing their presents, trees, and food for their Christmas feast. He crudely disguises himself as Santa Claus, and forces Max, disguised as a reindeer, to drag a sleigh to <b>Who</b>ville. Once there, the Grinch slides down the chimney and steals all of the <b>Who</b>s' Christmas presents, the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_tree" target="_blank" title="Christmas tree">Christmas tree</a>, and the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yule_log" target="_blank" title="Yule log">log</a>&nbsp;for their fire. He is briefly interrupted in his burglary by Cindy Lou, a little Who girl, but concocts a crafty lie to effect his escape from her home.</span></div>
